persona.name: Emilie Solheim

occupation.title: Student / Family caregiver (informal caretaker)
occupation.organization: Family household; attends public school and after-school programs
occupation.description: Emilie is primarily a 9th-grade student. At home she is the eldest sibling and often takes responsibility for looking after her two younger half-siblings (ages 6 and 3) when one or both parents are working late or attending appointments. Her 'job' at home includes preparing simple meals (sandwiches, pasta), dressing and supervising the children, reading bedtime stories, and calming them at night when needed. She sometimes babysits for neighbours or family friends for small amounts of pocket money and occasionally helps out at the local kindergarten as a short-term volunteer through the school's community program. Her responsibilities require time-management, basic first aid knowledge, conflict mediation skills between siblings, and the ability to plan simple weekday evenings and weekend activities. At school she participates in drama club and helps manage props, which gives her organizational experience. She wants a realistic occupational path (preschool/primary teacher), so she pays attention to child development topics and asks her teachers questions about pedagogy when she gets the chance.

persona.education: 9th grade at a local public lower secondary school (Ungdomsskole) in Eastern Oslo. Strongest subjects: Arts and Norwegian; struggles a bit with Mathematics. Participates in after-school club for drama and has attended two summer coding workshops run by the municipal youth centre. Receives occasional extra help in math from a resource teacher. Familiar with the school system's routines for electives and will choose studies/further education tracks next year (videregående planning conversations have started).
long_term_goals: Finish upper secondary school (videregående) and qualify for higher education.
Train to become a preschool teacher or primary school teacher (inspired by caring for younger siblings).
Live independently in her twenties but stay close to family in Oslo.
Build a small circle of trusted friends and possibly travel around Scandinavia with them.
Be financially independent and not rely on others for housing or basic needs.
Learn to play guitar well enough to accompany singing at family gatherings.
Improve confidence so she can speak up in class without anxiety.
Create a steady routine that balances school, hobbies, and caring responsibilities without burnout.
persona.style: Casual, warm, and slightly reserved. Emilie speaks Norwegian Bokmål with a soft Eastern Oslo accent (slight tonal rises at the ends of sentences when she is unsure). She mixes colloquial teen expressions with careful polite phrasing when speaking to adults. Her mannerisms: tucks hair behind her ear when thinking, smiles with one side of her mouth, fidgets with a bracelet when nervous. She uses a calm, measured pace when giving instructions to her younger siblings but becomes animated and louder when excited (for example, when acting in drama club). Her texting style is efficient—short sentences, emojis reserved for close friends (heart, laughing-crying, folded-hands). In school group work she is cooperative but defers to more outspoken peers unless she feels confident about a task. She avoids formal language except when writing school reports. She has a tendency to sigh softly before answering difficult questions. She prefers practical clothing—hoodies, jeans, sneakers—and layers because Oslo weather changes; she often wears a bright knitted hat in winter and a used denim jacket she decorated with safety-pins and a hand-drawn patch. When upset, she speaks more quietly and uses fewer gestures; when happy, she talks faster and uses bigger gestures.

traits: Responsibility-oriented: takes care of siblings reliably and feels accountable for household tasks.
Empathetic: attentive to other people's moods and quick to comfort younger children or friends in distress.
Cautiously curious: wants to try new things but first seeks reassurance and information.
Creative: enjoys drama, drawing, and role-play; improvises games for the kids.
Sensitive to criticism: internalizes remarks and replays them mentally.
Pragmatic: prefers straightforward solutions to messy conflicts.
Socially loyal: maintains a small but tight-knit group of friends and supports them consistently.
Occasionally anxious: experiences worry about school performance and balancing caregiving duties.
Adaptable: manages sudden schedule changes (parents' shifts, appointments) better than many peers.
Conscientious about promises: remembers small commitments (lend a pencil, water a plant) and feels guilty when she forgets.

openness.description: Curious and imaginative, enjoys drama and art, open to new experiences but cautious about major life changes.

conscientiousness.description: Highly responsible for her age, reliable with chores and caregiving, organized with school assignments when motivated.

extraversion.description: Moderate — comfortable with friends and small groups, quieter in large or unfamiliar settings.

agreeableness.description: Very cooperative, empathetic, and helpful; prioritizes harmony and support for others.

neuroticism.description: Moderate anxiety and sensitivity; experiences stress around school tests and when caretaking demands pile up.

interests: Drama and acting — enjoys improvisation games and short plays at school.
Children's literature — especially picture books and short chapter books she can read to her siblings.
Drawing and sketching characters and simple comics about daily life.
Listening to Norwegian pop and acoustic music (likes Astrid S and Sigrid) while doing chores.
Watching family-friendly TV series and carefully chosen teen dramas with friends.
Biking around the neighbourhood and short trips to nearby parks.
Taking photos on her phone of small everyday details (shadows, snacks, little feet).
Simple baking — muffins and cinnamon buns, often made with one sibling helping.
Trying basic coding puzzles learned in summer workshops (Scratch and block-based coding).
Role-playing games with friends where she often takes the mediator or storyteller role.
favorite_foods: Brown cheese (brunost) on crispbread — quick snack between school and caretaking.
Pasta with tomato sauce — easy to prepare for siblings.
Yoghurt with berries and granola for breakfast.
Small cinnamon twists (Skillingsboller) from the bakery on Saturdays.
Fruit smoothies when she has time to make them.
Pizza slices for an easy shared meal that children enjoy.
Simple salads with cucumbers and feta when trying to be healthy.
Chocolate occasionally, but prefers sharing a small bar rather than eating alone.
music_and_media: Likes upbeat Norwegian pop artists (Astrid S, Sigrid) and gentle acoustic playlists for evenings.
Listens to children's songs and sing-along playlists when with her siblings.
Enjoys short comedy sketches and family vlog channels in Norwegian on YouTube.
Follows one or two teen influencers from Oslo for fashion inspiration (mostly thrifted looks).
Occasionally listens to podcasts for kids about science and stories when doing chores.
games_and_toys: Board games she can play with 6-year-old (e.g., Memo, simple cooperative games).
Card games and simple role-play props from drama club.
Mobile puzzle games for short breaks (word puzzles, matching games).
Craft kits for making friendship bracelets — likes to make them as gifts.
school_subjects_and_learning: Enjoys Norwegian language, drama, and arts.
Interested in child development topics and informal caregiving strategies.
Less enthusiastic about mathematics but attends extra help sessions.
Likes group projects when roles are clearly defined.
social_media_and_communication: Uses Instagram and Snapchat lightly; private account shared only with close friends.
Communicates with parents via family group chat about schedules and tasks.
Uses a paper planner for family's shared appointments and school deadlines.
clothing_and_style_preferences: Prefers comfortable street-style clothes: hoodies, straight-leg jeans, sneakers.
Likes colourful knitted hats and patterned socks.
Favors layers because of unpredictable Oslo weather; keeps a small raincoat in her backpack.
Occasionally dresses up for school performances with thrifted dresses and homemade accessories.
hangout_places: Local playground by the canal for siblings' playtime.
After-school youth club for drama rehearsals and homework help.
Public library's youth section for quiet reading and borrowing books.
Small corner café where she meets one close friend once a month (prefers hot chocolate).
detailed_likes: Being trusted with small responsibilities and being thanked for them.
Short, well-organized plans for outings that include breaks for the younger kids.
Handwritten notes and simple, sincere compliments from teachers or family.
Stickers and little rewards for siblings when they cooperate.
Sunlight patterns on classroom walls in the afternoon.
Days when everything goes according to the schedule she planned.
detailed_dislikes: Being interrupted while preparing a sibling's meal.
Sudden loud arguments in the apartment that frighten the younger children.
Tests in math where she feels unprepared.
Adults who dismiss her ideas because she is 'just a kid'.
Long commutes that cut into the time she has for homework and siblings.

beliefs: Family responsibility is important: if you're old enough, you should help at home.
Children deserve calm routines; predictable schedules make them feel safe.
Teachers matter — a single encouraging teacher can change how someone sees themselves.
Hard work and small consistent efforts pay off academically and in everyday life.
Being kind is more valuable than being popular.
Friends are chosen carefully; a few loyal friends are better than many superficial acquaintances.
Public services (schools, youth clubs) should be accessible and supportive for families with working parents.
Adults should not expect perfect behavior from children; patience helps everyone.
Learning should include practical skills (cooking, first aid) as well as academic subjects.
City green spaces are essential for children's development and wellbeing.
Children's voices should be heard in municipal planning (playgrounds, school start times).
Scandinavian welfare principles help families balance work and childcare.
Saving a small amount of money regularly is smart even for teenagers.
It's okay to ask for help; asking doesn't mean you're weak.
Technology is useful but needs limits for small kids' healthy development.
Art and drama are as important as maths and languages; they help emotional growth.
Respect for neighbours is important — quiet hours should be observed.
Eating together as a family is valuable for bonding, even when schedules are busy.
Young people should be offered safe work opportunities that do not interfere with school.
It's acceptable to change your mind about future careers as you learn and grow.
Mental health conversations should be normalized in schools.
People make mistakes; apologies and small reparations are important.
Climate change feels real and scary; small everyday choices (less waste, recycling) matter.
Local culture and language are meaningful and should be preserved and celebrated.
Being organized reduces stress; lists and timetables help her manage responsibilities.
Parents and guardians should strive to balance work with quality time for children.
Neighbors can be part of an extended support network — borrowing a cup of sugar or watching a child briefly is community.
Public transportation should be reliable and safe for young people traveling alone.
Privacy is important; siblings should have their own space when possible.
School should include conversation about civic rights and responsibilities in an age-appropriate way.
Gender equality matters; both boys and girls should share household responsibilities.
Food security is important — no child should feel hungry at home or school.
Small acts of kindness (holding a door, sharing an umbrella) create a kinder community.
Young people should be trusted with responsibilities that match their abilities.
skills: Childcare: experienced in preparing snacks, organizing play, calming a crying toddler, reading aloud, and basic bedtime routines.
Basic first aid and safety awareness from school lessons and home practice: knows how to treat small cuts, apply a plaster, and when to seek adult/medical help.
Household management: can plan a simple evening routine, manage a small grocery checklist, and keep a modest budget for pocket money.
Cooking basics: makes pasta, sandwiches, simple baked goods (muffins), and warms ready-made meals safely.
Communication: calming tone for younger children, clear instructions, and conflict mediation among siblings and friends.
Organization: maintains a paper planner for appointments, schoolwork, and siblings' schedules.
Languages: Norwegian Bokmål native; basic English for school and media consumption; understands bits of Nynorsk through school texts.
Digital literacy: competent with smartphone apps (messaging, calendar, camera), social media privacy settings, and basic block coding (Scratch).
Drama and stagecraft basics: improvisation, simple stage props handling, and basic costume adjustments.
Photography: takes well-composed casual photos on her phone and edits them with simple filters.
Time management: divides time between schoolwork and caregiving, develops todo lists for evenings.
Empathy-based counselling: offers peer support informally to friends, listens actively and offers practical suggestions.
Problem-solving: pragmatic approaches to scheduling conflicts, uses checklists and fallback plans.
Cycling: comfortable riding in urban traffic and using bike lights and helmets properly.
Public transport navigation: knows the local bus and tram routes around Eastern Oslo relevant to school and activities.

general: Places siblings' needs ahead of personal leisure when there's a conflict.
Checks a small notebook daily for tasks and appointments and crosses off completed items.
Sings or hums quietly while cooking or cleaning to soothe younger siblings.
Fidgets with a friendship bracelet when nervous or thinking.
Prefers to resolve disputes by negotiation and small rewards rather than punishment.
Is more talkative and playful with children than with unfamiliar adults.
Often apologizes quickly if a sibling falls or a friend gets upset, even if not her fault.
Uses headphones to carve out quiet time when stressed and needs to study.

morning: Wakes at 06:30 on school days, makes a quick breakfast for herself and checks that siblings are dressed.
Helps prepare lunchboxes or arranges a simple packed lunch if parents are gone early.
Leaves for school by 08:00, sometimes checking in with parents via message about evening plans.
Carries a small backpack with the school planner, water bottle, drama props, and a modest first aid kit.
schoolday: Attends classes, participates actively in drama and arts, asks teachers for clarification when she is unsure.
Helps friends with small tasks like lending a pen or explaining a part of a drama script.
Eats lunch quickly with friends and sometimes swaps a snack with a sibling later.
Attends after-school drama club twice a week; uses this time also for homework if siblings are asleep when she gets home.
evening: Returns home between 15:30 and 16:30 depending on caretaking duties and activities.
Prepares a simple shared dinner or reheats leftovers, supervises homework for younger sibling.
Reads a bedtime story to the 3-year-old and sings a short song before sleep.
Studies or completes school assignments for an hour after younger siblings are in bed, then relaxes with a short TV program or music.
Checks the family group chat for the next day's schedule before bed.
weekend: Saturday: bakery run in the morning, drama rehearsal or youth club in the afternoon, family time, and a friend meet-up at a café.
Sunday: quieter day for household chores, planning the week's meals, preparing schoolbags, and a long walk in a nearby park if weather permits.
Occasionally babysits for neighbours for pocket money, combining it with a quick outing to the playground.

physical.general_health: Generally healthy and active for her age.
physical.chronic_conditions: Mild seasonal pollen allergy (sneezing, itchy eyes) treated with OTC antihistamine when needed.
physical.vision: Wears prescription glasses part-time for reading and screen work; mild myopia.
physical.growth_and_nutrition: Normal growth for age; sometimes skips full meals when busy but tries to eat regular snacks.
physical.dental: Routine dental check-ups; one small cavity filled at age 12.
physical.vaccinations: Up-to-date with Norwegian childhood vaccination schedule.
physical.sleep: Averages 8–9 hours on good nights, but sleep can be reduced when anxious or when siblings wake at night.
physical.exercise: Regular light exercise via cycling and playground play; drama rehearsals provide moderate physical activity.

mental.general_mental_health: Emotionally mature for her age given responsibilities but prone to stress and occasional low-level anxiety.
mental.stress_triggers: School tests, conflicts between parents, nights when younger siblings are ill.
mental.coping_strategies: Talks with close friend or one trusted teacher, writes short notes in a pocket journal, listens to calming music.
mental.support: Has access to school counselling services; parents are aware of her stress and try to provide support though they are sometimes busy.
mental.professional_help: No ongoing therapy, but has used one-off school counsellor sessions for guidance on managing time and stress.
mental.behavioral_indicators: Becomes quieter, more withdrawn, and more forgetful when under prolonged stress; may develop headaches from screen overuse.

relationships.name: Maren Solheim
relationships.description: Works shift hours at a municipal health clinic. Warm but often tired. Close with Emilie; relies on Emilie for household coordination during late shifts. Supports Emilie's schooling but sometimes feels guilty about how busy work is.

relationships.name: Anders Solheim
relationships.description: Works as a tram technician in Oslo. Practical, good-humoured, teaches Emilie bike mechanics basics. Not always present in evenings due to overtime, but engages actively on weekends. Encourages Emilie's interest in practical crafts.

relationships.name: Lina (little sibling)
relationships.description: Bright, energetic, loves being read to. Emilie acts as a secondary caregiver and playmate; they have a close, affectionate relationship.

relationships.name: Jakob (little sibling)
relationships.description: Affectionate toddler who often seeks Emilie's lap at the end of the day. Emilie is protective and amused by his antics.

relationships.name: Sofie Nygård
relationships.description: Same grade, met in drama club. Confidante, co-planner for outings and school projects. Sofie is more extroverted and often encourages Emilie to try new things.

relationships.name: Kjell (neighbour)
relationships.description: Lives in the same building, checks in on the family. Gives Emilie small life advice and sometimes helps pick up siblings from kindergarten.

relationships.name: Ms. Berg
relationships.description: Encouraging mentor figure who noticed Emilie's leadership in rehearsal and suggested volunteer experience at the kindergarten program.

relationships.name: School counsellor
relationships.description: Available for periodic check-ins about stress, balance, and school planning; Emilie has used the service once and knows how to access it again.

relationships.name: Extended family
relationships.description: Live in nearby parts of Oslo and visit monthly; provide occasional childcare backup and small gifts. Emilie enjoys the grandparents' stories about Oslo's past.

other_facts: Born and raised in Oslo; has lived in the same apartment building in Grünerløkka since age 4.
Speaks Bokmål at home; family occasionally uses a few dialect words from Eastern Oslo.
Has a small hand-drawn patch on her denim jacket made during a school art project that she treasures.
Keeps a little pocket notebook where she writes quick to-do lists, story ideas, and sometimes short dialogues for drama scenes.
Won a small school award for a short play she co-wrote in 7th grade about a neighbourhood hero.
Once organized a neighborhood treasure hunt for younger kids; learned to create clear clues and manage groups of children safely.
Is motivated by praise from adults she respects — a teacher's word of encouragement can lift her confidence for days.
Has a routine 'quiet corner' in the living room where she studies and reads, decorated with fairy lights.
Was taught basic bike maintenance by her father and helped fix a flat tire on a rainy day — felt proud and grown-up afterward.
Is registered in the local youth centre's drama program and received a small municipal grant once to attend a weekend theatre camp.
Keeps one small stuffed animal from toddlerhood that she uses to soothe her youngest sibling at night.
Collects simple stickers and uses them as rewards for her 6-year-old when completing small tasks.
Has a scar on her left knee from falling while trying to skateboard at age 10; it's a funny family anecdote now.
Is learning how to use the tram and bus system routes independently, with a checklist for safety when travelling with siblings.
Has an older cousin who studies at university who occasionally advises her about videregående choices.
Has a favorite library corner seat where she sits and sketches and has memorized the weekly librarian's schedule.
Once helped a friend prepare for a reading presentation by practicing voice projection and pacing with them.
Dreams of a short trip to Bergen to see the fjords with her family in the future; talks about it with excitement during mealtimes.
Has attended two municipal parenting workshops (with her mother) about child nutrition and sleep routines; learned practical tips she uses.
Is careful about social media privacy and helped a younger cousin set account privacy settings.
Has a small emergency kit in her backpack (plasters, tissue, a small antiseptic wipe) because she often cares for others spontaneously.
Often arranges simple theme evenings (film night, pizza night) to create relaxed family time when parents are home.
Finds comfort in certain rituals: a cup of warm tea before school planning meetings and a short stretching routine after drama rehearsals.
Is proud of remembering most relatives' birthdays and often draws cards for them.
Has a recurring dream of performing a solo scene on a proper stage; this dream motivates her drama practice.
Has once mediated a playground conflict between older kids by proposing a simple 'turn-taking' rule to play a game fairly.
Remembers small details about people (favorite snacks, allergies, favourite stories) and uses them to make others feel cared for.
Has a personal rule: 'If you say you'll help, you do it' — she holds herself strictly to commitments and sometimes expects the same from others.
Uses a colourful calendar on the kitchen wall to coordinate school events, parents' shifts, and sibling appointments.
Is learning to budget her small earnings, saving a portion each month for a desired guitar.
Had a moment of pride when the drama teacher publicly praised her for calming a stage mishap during last term's performance.
Is cautious about loud fireworks because younger siblings get scared; prefers quieter celebrations and hand-held sparklers when permitted.
Organizes a small 'story hour' with the younger kids on Sunday evenings — reads aloud and asks them simple questions to encourage language skills.
Likes to write short letters to her grandparents and mails them occasionally, enjoying the slower, more personal communication.
Once organized a mini fundraising bake sale with friends to buy extra art supplies for the school; learned about cooperation and small-scale planning.
Enjoys small acts of rebellion like mismatched socks and safety-pin decorations while still dressing modestly for family events.
Values routines but can improvise in emergencies — learned this from multiple nights when parents worked late and plans had to change.
Remembers a childhood moment when a neighbor comforted her after a fall; it shaped her belief in community kindness and now she tries to 'be that neighbor' for others.
